hints_html:
Notice that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A^TA = A^*A = (U\Sigma V^*)^*(U\Sigma V^*) = V\Sigma^2V^*\end{aligned}\]

Since V is real and orthogonal, \(\displaystyle V^* = V^T = V^{-1}\) so that the equation above describes an eigenvalue decomposition.

For an eigenvalue decomposition \(\displaystyle M = TDT^{-1}\), the eigenvalues of M fill the diagonal of D, and the eigenvectors of M are the column vectors of T.
hints_latex:
Notice that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
A^TA = A^*A = (U\Sigma V^*)^*(U\Sigma V^*) = V\Sigma^2V^*
\end{align*} Since
\emph{V} is real and orthogonal, $\displaystyle V^* = V^T = V^{-1}$ so
that the equation above describes an eigenvalue decomposition.

For an eigenvalue decomposition $\displaystyle M = TDT^{-1}$, the
eigenvalues of \emph{M} fill the diagonal of \emph{D}, and the
eigenvectors of \emph{M} are the column vectors of \emph{T}.
hints_raw:
Notice that

:<math> \displaystyle
A^TA = A^*A = (U\Sigma V^*)^*(U\Sigma V^*) = V\Sigma^2V^*
</math>
Since ''V'' is real and orthogonal, <math>\displaystyle V^* = V^T = V^{-1}</math> so that the equation above describes an eigenvalue decomposition.
For an eigenvalue decomposition <math>\displaystyle M = TDT^{-1} </math>, the eigenvalues of ''M'' fill the diagonal of ''D'', and the eigenvectors of ''M'' are the column vectors of ''T''.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
From the eigenvalue decomposition

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A^TA = V\Sigma^2V^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

we see that the eigenvalues of ATA are the squares of the diagonal entries in \(\displaystyle \Sigma\), that is

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda_{1}=4, \quad \lambda_{2}=1, \quad \lambda_{3}=\frac{1}{4}\end{aligned}\]

Further, the corresponding eigenvectors of ATA are the column vectors of V, namely

\[\begin{aligned} \vec{v_{1}}=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \end{bmatrix} , \quad \vec{v_{2}}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \end{bmatrix} , \quad \vec{v_{3}}=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{2}{\sqrt{6}}\\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}\\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Suppose that A is a matrix with singular value decomposition \(A = U\Sigma V^*\) where

\[\begin{aligned} U &= \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \\ \Sigma &= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix} \\ V &= \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 3 & 0 & 2/\sqrt 6 \\ 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6 \\ 1/\sqrt 3 & -1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

(b) What are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of \(A^T A\)? (Note

\[\begin{aligned} A^T = A^*\end{aligned}\]

since A is real.)
statement_raw:
Suppose that ''A'' is a matrix with singular value decomposition <math>A = U\Sigma V^*</math> where

:<math>
\begin{align}
U = & \begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix} \\
\Sigma = & \begin{bmatrix}
2 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1/2
\end{bmatrix} \\
V = & \begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 3 & 0 & 2/\sqrt 6 \\
1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6 \\
1/\sqrt 3 & -1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align}
</math>

'''(b)''' What are the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of <math>A^T A</math>? (Note: <math> A^T = A^*</math> since ''A'' is real.)
